Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: A 'holistic' approach toward scalable quantum optical networks in semiconductors
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this work we investigate a new qubit system ideal for realizing an optically connected quantum network: single acceptor-bound holes (A0) in III-V quantum wells (QW). This system has the potential to combine millisecond long spin coherence times with strong, homogeneous optical transitions in a nanofabrication-ready material. Far-field super-resolution optical techniques will be developed in order to isolate single impurity-bound excitons (A0X), with the goal of reaching optical resolutions on the order of the effective mass Bohr radius. These techniques will be combined with ultrafast optical spin control to study the effect of QW confinement and nearby surfaces on the optical and spin coherence properties of the A0-A0X system. Knowledge gained from these studies will guide research on integrating single impurities into optical nanocavities. The longer term goal of the project is to realize optically-connected few qubit devices in a scalable architecture.

A quantum information network based on photons and spins would enable quantum simulation, secure long-distance quantum communication, and quantum computation. In this work we study single impurities in semiconductors as potential quantum bits for such a network. Nanoscale low temperature imaging techniques will be developed to isolate single impurities. Ultrafast optical techniques will be used to study the impurity qubit lifetime. The longer term goal of the project is to realize a few qubit network in which spins are connected through on-chip optical devices. The research program will involve, teach, and train undergraduates, graduate students, and postdoctoral associates in experimental physics, quantum optics, and nanoscience. In addition to training undergraduate students, graduate students and postdocs in quantum optics, physics and nanotechnology, an integral part of the broader impact of this program includes community outreach at a local elementary school. University of Washington physics and electrical engineering students, working closely with a Sansislo elementary school science teacher, are engaging 4th-5th grade students in weekly science activites aimed at understanding light.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The award sought to determine the suitability of several semiconductor platforms for applications in quantum information.  Semiconductors which efficiently emit light, otherwise known as direct bandgap semiconductors, were targeted due to their suitability for photon-enabled applications. These applications include quantum communication and photon-mediated computational gates for quantum computation.  

The following lists specific outcomes related to the Intellectual Merit of the project.

Determination of the suitability of acceptors as qubit candidates:  We experimentally confirmed the excited state structure and radiative lifetimes of acceptor-bound excitons in the semiconductor gallium arsenide (GaAs). The agreement with theory confirms that the dominant relaxation measurement is radiative which is important for photon-mediated applications. In strained GaAs, longitudinal spin relaxation measurements were performed showing showing microsecond relaxation times. Transverse ensemble relaxations times, determined by coherent population trapping measurements, were found to be on the order of nanoseconds and most likely limited by strain inhomogeneities. These spin measurements indicate that shallow acceptors in strained III-V semiconductors do not exhibit the desirable spin properties for quantum applications.

Determination of the donor electron longitudinal spin relaxation times and mechanisms in 4 semiconductors. These results quantitatively determine the mechanism for spin relaxation in the high B-field limit for donors in GaAs, CdTe, InP, and ZnO. A theoretical framework is developed that can be applied to a larger class off direct bandgap semiconductors, serving as a predictive tool for the suitability of donors as qubits in a targeted direct bandgap semiconductor. We determined ZnO to be a promising qubit candidate.

Discovery of highly homogeneous two-dimensional (2D) excitonic potentials in GaAs. We measure the optical properties of excitons bound to 10-micron-scale stacking faults in GaAs. We found that the 2D potential is highly homogeneous, an important feature for quantum applications. We also measured the built-in dipole moment of the mobile, 2D exciton.  We found this dipole to be large (10 nm) indicating exciton-exciton interactions are strong. These results indicate that stacking fault excitons may be promising for many-body simulations of interacting bosons. The behavior of such systems cannot be simulated on our current computers due to the complexity of the quantum interactions.

Determination of spin relaxation properties of donors in ZnO: We perform a complete spin study of Ga donors in ZnO determining a longitudinal spin relaxation time exceeding 100 ms,  a transverse dephasing time of 17 ns, and a spin-echo dephasing times of 50 microseconds, in a commercial substrate. These results indicate that that ZnO donors are be a promising qubit candidate which combines the attractive features of donors in Si with an optically accessible material for photon-mediated quantum information applications.

5 peer reviewed publications resulted from the work including two which were highlighted in their journals as Editor’s Suggestions. The results were disseminated in 30 conference presentations and invited seminars/colloquiums, including 11 given by postdocs/students.

The following lists specific outcomes related to the Broader Impacts of the project.

One postdoctoral associate, 3 PhD students and 12 undergraduates were trained on this project.  Areas of training included optical design and instrumentation, automated instrument control and data acquisition, data analysis, semiconductor physics, and quantum mechanical simulations. The postdoc is now the founder of an optical start-up company and the PhD student who has graduated is now employed at a government lab. 5 of the undergraduates are now in physics PhD programs.

 A graduate-student run elementary school science and engineering outreach program, the UW Science Explorers, was established and sustained (6 years and still on-going.) The outreach program conducts three 8-week units at Sanislo Elementory, a southwest Seattle public school that was noted  in 2016 as the most diverse school in the state of Washington. Graduate students interacted with the same 20-25 4th and 5th graders weekly each quarter. 4th and 5th grade participants were chosen chosen each quarter by the elementary school teacher participant as students would would particularly benefit from sustained science enrichment activities. All lessons/activities are publically accessible at (http://uwscienceexplorers.weebly.com).  

During the course of the award, the PI participated in many activities aimed at broadening the participation of women in science. She served as a Women in Science and Engineering (WiSE) mentor and a Washington State Academic RedShirt (STARS) mentor. She was an invited speaker/workshop leader at two Conferences for Undergraduate Women in Physics (CUWiP), and is the chair of the 2019 CUWiP at the University of Washington which will host 180 aspiring women physicists.
